description: The well maintained dirt roads through Olney State Forest
offer a unique chance to access a very remote section of the Great North Walk in relative comfort.
As well as one of the highest peaks and vantage points in the area.

markers.description: Plan your drive to The Basin Campground.
From the carpark of the Basin Campground follow the sign to the Great North Walk.
At intersections follow the Great North Walk signs.
At the intersection with the Cedar Brush Walk, follow the Great North Walk along the creek.
The trail along the creek ends at a rocky creek crossing.
After crossing the creek, follow the track zigzagging up the ridge.
At the top of the climb, follow the firetrail along the ridge.
At the intersections follow the Great North Walk sign down Wild Boar Road.
At the intersection with Pig and Sow Ridge, look for the fainter bushtrail across the track continuing the Great North Walk
A sign and a walkers log marks the start of the trail.
The trail descends to a creek and ascends the next ridge on the other side.
At the top of the next ridge, follow the Great North Walk signs down the firetrail.
At the intersection follow Murray Forest Road to the right for a short distance.
Enter the first intersection on the left, following the signs for the Great North Walk.
A fainter bushtrail continues to the right of the firetrail.
Where the bushtrail rejoins the firetrail follow the Great North Walk sign to the right.
At the intersection follow the Great North Walk sign.
At the intersection with Warrawolong Road, follow the Great North Walk to the right.
Take the next intersection left down Turners Road.
Follow the last stretch to the lookouts, watching carefully for vantage points on the right. They are not signposted.
Several vantage points offer views across the valley and Watagan Creek.
From the lookouts return to the intersection to Mount Warrawalong.
Follow the sign left down Warrawolong Road if time allows. +1.5h / 3km
A trail up to the summit will be apparent on the left.
The summit contains a grass clearing and watchtower. There are only filtered views between the trees.
Check carefully for signs if climbing the tower is (still) allowed.
The top of the watchtower offers a wide open view across the wilderness and Central Coast.
From Mount Warrawolong follow the Great North Walk back to Murrays Forest Road.
Instead of following the Cedar Brush Walk to the right, follow the alternative route to the left following Murrays Forest Road.
At the intersection follow Walkers Ridge Road to the right.
At the intersection with the Basin Forest Road, follow the signs to the Basin Campground.
Plan your drive back from The Basin Campground.
